comments.commentBody:
M. Colman:

You are clearly smart and well educated.

What you fail to recognize is that many of those who need coverage outside of your State have never bought insurance before. They didn't benefit from the privileges you take for granted.

They don't know what "co-payment" or "premium" mean, nor the meaning of any of the essential information you and I know intuitively. That is not elitist. It's our reality in today's America.

It's a huge challenge to right these inequities.

For reasons too complex to explain here, what works in Washington State does not translate to the Deep South.

Cut them some slack.

Please tell us your monthly premium and deductible.

Guaranteed your premium is higher and your deductible is at least 4 times higher than prior to the ACA.

My state's site is also up and running. In 2013 we definitely need coverage as a nation. Now those who do have health care coverage pay for those who don't. 'Getting sick' does not care.
With any technology system as extensive as this there will be glitches that are not apparent until it has been rolled out. Deep breath people. Look at the long term goal.

The feds should look at Washington state's exchange for a model.  I can go and use a calculator to see what plans will cost, what subsidy is and what plans are available before signing up for anything.

Where have you been?

President Obama has not been silent. He is concerned but as he's not a programmer he can't fix it himself.

Many members of Congress, none of whom are programmers but all of whom have excellent healthcare, have made statements as well.

I don't think the American people are, in the case of the President, "out of sight" or "out of mind". Isn't it time to come to terms with who this President is? He has been attacked non-stop since he took office. Be honest with your self and ask why this is the case.
Exactly. "Let them eat cake"
President Obama seems contentedly silent on the failed ACA enrollment. Perhaps because he already is enrolled with healthcare for his family. Out of sight, out of mind.

The students on IEPs are not given the support needed to really make them work. That is why it is a problem for teachers. They simply cannot do it all. And I think teachers are poorly equipped to work with any child who has special needs.

Sooner or later the US population will have to face up to the fact that the entire economic, legal, military and big-industrial system - the last part of which would seem to be reduced to the aggression industry, since all the rest have moved out to exploit cheap labor in foreign countries, leaving the beloved Homeland or Wasteland as an underdeveloping neo-Third-World territory to be later recolonized by the "muttinationals" when wages have dropped to a Bangladesh level in Ohio and Michigan - is in the hands of a network of mafias which, unlike the ones in the movies, waste no time in family feuds that can be better spent splitting up the booty. The chaos and misery the US has produced in Afghanistan, Iraq, Libya and Syria have to wash back. The chickens have come home to roost.

You can analyze situations like this one to death, but it's not an isolated incident. There is a big picture, and it's very ugly.

Excellent comment, David. I would only add that it would be nice if a billion dollars of the settlement went to educate the American public on what the rip-offs were all about and how they actually worked, perhaps with simply-done ads in local newspapers and mass market magazines, as well as commercials on right-wing radio talk shows and "underwritings" on public radio stations.

Sadly, this sum is small (we know the $4 billion in "help" to homeowners will be window dressing. My daughter was always a bit quirky but in an endearing way. In second grade we began to notice academic problems--her reading comprehension was terrible. We struggled to find something to help her, as according to the school psychologist, she was fine.

After fifth grade, we took her for private testing. The outcome was bizarre--very low IQ, yet very high academic scores. The diagnosis was anxiety (which shocked everyone who knew her) and counseling was recommended. I consulted with a counselor we knew, and her recommendation was to do nothing. She felt that putting her into counseling might actually cause anxiety where none of us could see any before. We agreed.

Good call. When she was 17, we finally got a diagnosis, of a rare brain anomaly. Turns out she is extremely high functioning for having this condition, which only 3% survive to be born alive. Some of the social comprehension can cause some anxiety, but that anxiety was and is certainly not the cause of her academic problems.

You are absolutely correct.  It's not a simple matter of building a website, it is the extremely complex back-end systems that make this a difficult project.  It was made more difficult by changing and late requirements, which is typical for government contracts.  And CMS should never have taken on the role of primary contact and coordinator for all of the contractors involved, they do not have the staff or the expertise.

ACA is a great theory on paper/text yet is proving itself to be a horrible designed practice with problems that just keep creeping up!

Thus I do believe it would be best to toss it out and go back and develop a Universal Health Care system for All Americans no matter of income level.

Illegal Immigrants do have some money so if they have emergency health needs they can pay what they can, but We the Americans deserve better than ACA and a Universal Health Care Program would provide such!

And I am sure that our Government could model one after countries that have successfully implemented such!

For years we have been asking Mr. Obama for leadership, now is the time that he could as our leader and the President we elected! Be A leader MR. President and do is what is best for Americans. ACA is not worthy of such frustration anger and confusion!
I'm sure that guy in India will "do the needful."

Many people will say that this site should have been easy to create, after all, new websites are built all the time, right?  Wrong.  A few years ago I worked for a start-up that sold health insurance online.  It was a big task to get the site built, largely because of the complexity of insurance plans and how every private carrier structures them differently and uses different rules.  When I imagine what it must have been like to support exchanges in every participating state, it's nightmarish.  People need to understand, it's not the web pages that are hard to build.  It's all of the back-end systems.  Even a couple of years might not be enough time to get it right out of the gate.  And if they used overseas contractors, you can forget about ever getting it right.

@Robert, 10 person payroll and 100,000 payroll are payroll but the complexity scales up depending on various factors

When an existing system has a glitch, it confines to certain subsystem, frontend, backend, middleware etc. When a brand new system spanning 50 states and with identity subsystems interfacing existing Federal and maybe even State systems, you have a serious problem

I have worked in IT for 30 years and half a billion line software system, not to mention the configuration of hardware, is a difficult if possible task to fix

Perhaps the IT planning of ACA was flawed but people who don't know systems design and development should not think it is a cake walk. They only reflect their own ignorance

Gee, Robert, you don't think there's a small difference between fixing a problem in an existing website that's been up and running for years and building a new system from scratch?  Maybe "conservatives" should try to get a better grasp of business problems in the Internet age.

Microsoft has given us the best counter-example to your premises, Robert.

Microsoft has spent over 20 years "developing" its operating system software.

They still don't have it "right".

After that length of time, why did it take over an hour with at least two automatic reboots just to install their latest fixes for Windows 7 on my computer?

I takes Amazon or Google like an hour or two to fix their sites when they are down, and the US government can't fix its site for a few more weeks or months?  Maybe liberals should rethink their philosophy when it comes to big government.
LOL. Apparently you have very little knowledge of government work. A week equals a month at the least. As a former fed employee I have seen it more that any other time frame.

A properly functioning system is months away. Perhaps many months. The people saying "weeks" are afraid to level with us. The testing alone will run a minimum of two months for a project like this, no matter what anyone else has to do.

I strongly support the ACA, so of course I hope that I'm being too pessimistic. But on the other hand, this is the sort of thing I do for a living.
Weeks away?  I think we'll survive, and so will the ACA.
And Hispanic.
The article actually quoted five million lines of code.  This is entirely within reason to interact with hundreds of different databases and insurance companies.  Please read the article first.
Keith, at the end of the article, a tech is cited as saying the ACA site has 500 million lines of code. The 5 million figure is what another (?) tech says will probably need to be rewritten.

I am truly awed by my ignorance regarding the subjects of computer software design and systems engineering.  Thank you for trying to explain these very complex issues to me, a person who sort of knows what a mouse is, how to type with more than 2 fingers, and how to turn my computer on.  I simply had no idea of the complexity.

The web site does not have 500 million lines of software code, unless they are including the operating system, the web server, the router code, the load sharing modules, the database code, and nearly every other line of assembly code used to access hardware across the entire internet used by those between their service providers and the reverse proxy responsible for routing request to each instance of the software. Why do people quote these kind of numbers?

If the number is anywhere near that, then there no chance small updates will do anything but cause untested integration errors that have not been put into the automated testing system - if one exists.

What good is the substance if the vehicle to implement it is faulty?

I know pure blood Democrats are having a good old time blaming everything that goes wrong lately on Republicans (and they certainly deserve their share of the blame for the state the country is in) but this is a botched mess that could have lingering affects on how many people enroll in the program, which could dismantle it completely. It depends on having as many people as possible sign up.

Obama promised a site that would be as easy to navigate as amazon.com. This isn't that.
The ACA proper is the hard part. And Obama's crew couldn't even do the easy part. A lot of solace in that

Really? How long has it taken to clean up the Fannie/Freddie SNAFU?

Block grants and vouchers. Easier than incompetent GS-9s.

Appalling as this roll-out has been, we should all remember that the the ACA is the substance, and the website is just the vehicle to implement it. The vehicle will be fixed, and we should stop obsessing over its temporary stalling.

My daughter is 15 years old. She transferred here to Florida with me, my wife and my son. She has had a lot of adjustment issues since moving here to Florida. She started in a high school here and did not want to go. She yelled and cried everyday. She moved from Nevada with us here due to relocation due to employment.

We moved right next to the school she would be going to to make it easier for her. It was not enough. The school is big and there are a lot of kids there which she found overwhelming.

She is also as we found out having some female issues as we took her to the Doctor to address them. She has been seeing a psychologist here in the area. I have never never had contact with a counselor before. I guess I am learning that my kids are not perfect. She is being homeschooled now through me and my wife and on-line classes.

She is very lethargic and I am worried about her emotional and mental state. She sleeps a lot sayng that she is tired. She lets her schoolwork go after being an A student in Nevada. I miss my daughter! I am doing everything I can to get her back on track but it is not working. I even contacted a boarding school.

I just do not know what to do. She was born in Italy and my wife has a lot of family there. We thought about sending her back due to the familiarity with the place
I too am scared and nervous for my daughter's future.

What is really happening?  If you exclude for profit institutions, are there really more college students?  The for profit colleges are the worst form or fraud.  They offer nothing to their students, bilk the taxpayers for loans and grants, and have very high default rates ont the student loans they cause.  Burn them down.
They need to talk about site hits, because they won't say how many people have actually worked their way through it. those numbers would create a panic.
I agree, stop talking about visitors to the exchange site.  Lets do what this administration is all about.  Lets talk about visitors tours of the White House.

Agree with your basic skeptcisim, however, many are careful to describe the number of *unique* visitors--and it's millions.

What appalled me are the scores of reporters and gawkers who have tried logging on--that just compounds the problems. I was curious, too, but I've stayed away from a sense of ethics and respect for those who *actually* are seeking insurance. There seem to be real issues but, frankly, I wouldn't be surprised if we discover two things:

1. A systematic Tea Party campaign to flood the system--numbers, false information, etc.

2. Tea Party zealots have hacked the system to undermine it.

And behind them will be funding and coodination by Heritage Action, Koch brothers, Club for Growth, ALEC, etc.

I wish the White House would stop talking about he number of visitors to the exchange site! Its a dumb stat to reference. Are these unique monthly visitors? That might illustrate interest in the exchanges.

If these numbers reflect everyone who's tried accessing the site 10 times and failed to do so, then those numbers are a joke.

However we all are going to be part of that history, and I want all to be part of a better American. That is not the case with the Tea Party aka the Koch Brothers and their kind. There is a cruelty that I never thought I would see in this country and it is sickening to see, especially since it may not end in my lifetime and I am 70. Krugman is crying into the night that we need to help those that cannot help themselves, but not enough of us are listening and the far right is doing all in its power to quash helping the poor and disinfranchised.

What does it say about their side, when they are unable to engage in a honest conversation? That their main tactics involve sidetracking and inundating the debate with fallacies rooted in appeals to solidarity (a relic in racial politics), appeals to fear, appeals to ignorance?

Please Professor Krugman, this is the caucus that continues to insult our intelligence with maliciously crafted, transparently expedient, outright false information, tempered with reckless abandon and profligate disregard for truth and honesty.

Quite honestly, without the ability to flood and distract, their game would be up, and they would be revealed as the frauds, and conspiracy theorists they are.

This is the caucus that rejects thinking, science, math, and history. It's not a surprise that they can't debate coherently, let alone debate in good faith.

This is the Tea Party and their Republican lackeys we're talking about! With them, they're always a wild card, stymieing, stifling, and baffling us at every twist and turn!

With them, they never fail to surprise! With the gov't shutdown under our belt, I KNOW it is safe to say, 'what we think shouldn't happen, will, and what we think should happen, won't.'

Boy, adding the element of Murphy's Law to governing must feel nice in troubled times like these!

Quite honestly, debating with a zealot incapable of individual thought (which is what most Tea Partiers are) is a waste of time.

Instead, just let the results and history do the talking.

It's one thing for people to have trouble logging on to the site, but it's something else altogether when, after someone has actually managed to log on and sign up, the enrollment info gets lost, sent to the wrong insurer, the wrong state, etc. This seems to indicate that even if people go into a place where they get in-person help, the enrollment may still not go through, or end up in the wrong place.

So i hope everyone who enrolls saves whatever proof of that enrollment they have, and if they don't receive something in the mail within a couple of weeks, follow up on it. In the end, I imagine the exchanges will be required provide insurance as of Jan. 1 for anyone who can prove they signed up by Dec. 15. But I imagine the key will be proof.

The subsidy can kick in right away, so it has to be known upon enrollment.

And yes; these secondary systems can vary all over the place...

Seems like some clarification would be in order.  For one, don't people have to pay money before they're considered enrolled?  I imagine that quite a few people, especially those expecting a subsidy, might be reluctant to pay as yet.  Second, if the federal system has to connect with myriad state and private systems, isn't it likely that some of those secondary systems are themselves old and unreliable?
You're comparing apples and oranges.  Fixing an existing site and shaking the bugs out of a brand new site aren't at all the same thing.

Yes, all of the "actors" on the Hill and at Fox News, who are "acting" like this is the worst disaster in American history.

They would be relieved to know that they don't have to work very hard to manufacture another fake crisis to scare voters into voting for them in 2014.

Funny how the delay would land right in the middle of election season.

Statements like this show how much lots of people don't understand the urgency that obtaining health insurance has for many people.

It just needs to get fixed asap. That's the only thing that can sensibly be said.

It depends on the approach that is taken to fix the problems. When I read that the federal government was going to set up exchanges for the states who are refusing to participate, I thought they were going to build a system for each state in the same way that participating states were building their own exchange systems. It appears the federal government tried to build 1 mammoth system to handle exchanges for all the non-participating states. That, to me, was the biggest mistake. From all I have read so far, the systems that the participating states built, have not been experiencing the problems that the federal system is  experiencing.

sounds more like months than "weeks" will be required to straighten out this nightmarish maze of problems.  i suspect a delay in implementation and enforcement of the individual mandate by a year would be a relief to all actors.

Anetliner Netliner: I agree with ~95% of your suggestions. Particularly getting the President and the Congressional leadership out of the way. Notably, about half the Nation's people hate the former person while the other half hate the latter group. (Hate may be too strong a word ... but I can't think of anything more descriptively accurate right now.)

I think it would be much better to authorize Continuing Resolutions and Debt Ceiling increases until the beginning of Fiscal 2017 (2018?). I seriously doubt there can be anything like reasonable consensus and/or accommodation between the folks representing such dichotomous views on the proper duty of government (Lincoln: the only duty of government is to do for the People what the People cannot do for themselves).

In other words, let's give the folks *WE* elected not only a chance to cool off ... but, moreover, a chance for *US* to elect people who understand that--unlike dictatorships--representative democracies are built upon compromise that gives all stakeholders a *WIN*--"something is always better than nothing."

Compromise, btw, lubricates the Congressional engine ...

Furthermore, removing the twin threats of shutdown & default will give those seeking "certainty" the certainty they crave ...

Lastly, I think the Fed can do some direct stimulus by using QE to fund an Infrastructure Bank. Our Nation is falling apart. Plus, we need the *JOBS*!

Ike did it: The National Defense, Rebuilding America, & Beating China Bank.

I agree with both writers that a year-long Continuing Resolution and debt ceiling extension are mandatory.

Going further, I'd support repeal of the law requiring that Congress approve debt ceiling increases. Failing such repeal, I'd suggest reinstating the Gephardt Rule or something similar: that all needed debt ceiling increases related to approved budgets or Continuing Resolutions are "deemed approved". As well, a new rule providing for the automatic continuation of the current federal budget if the fiscal year expires without a new budget, would prevent the repetition of forced government shutdowns and create an incentive for compromise.

I also endorse Keith Hennessey's suggestion that Congressional negotiators hammer out a deal before Congressional leadership or the White House become involved. As well, I agree that Joe Biden is the best representative the White House has in completing complex deals with Congress, a fact that argues strongly for a Biden presidency in 2017.

A key item that has been left out of this debate is growing income inequality. The top 1% and other top earners are doing great, while the middle class and the poor are falling behind. That is a powerful argument for additional federal stimulus and the imposition of additional taxes on the most affluent. The Republican position of "no new taxes" is ludicrous and out of step with reality. Similarly, increased stimulus and economic growth will further grow revenues and balance the budget.

mancuroc's points cannot be too often repeated.  So-called libertarians ignore them at the (largely theoretical, so far) peril of getting what they wish for and finding out it is the jungle, which it plainly would be (except in science fiction stories).

A free market, as far as it is ever allowed, is subject to wild swings.  A mechanical device like a steam engine cannot function without a governor (the regulator).  It goes wild and destroys itself.  Mechanical engineers know that.  The libertarians don't like to think about it, except when doing mechanical engineering.
Not only true, but obvious except to the blind.  Sorry, libertarians.  Stick to writing interesting science fiction novels.

GlobalTraveller,
You may be right from a purely capitalist (not humane) standpoint. But there's no way you could get rid of 3rd party payments for regular health maintenance. The whole medical and pharmaceutical industry would fight that tooth and nail.

If we had no third-party insurance, medical costs as a percentage of our economy would undoubtedly go down. But medicine wouldn't be something you'd go into to make money. Also, the US would cease to be a center of medical innovation. People with lots of money could go to doctors who would offer the latest treatments from Europe or Canada, where there is third-party money to pay for developing them. The rest of us would get whatever treatments have existed up to now. And certain kinds of things, like MRI's, might become unnavailable because it might be too expensive to keep the machines running without the influx of insurance money.

Let's spell out moocher states; states that receive more in government assistance than they pay out in taxes.  The reddest of red states fall into this category for the most part.  It is the northeast, north mid-west, like Illinois and the west coast states that pay out more than they taken in.  These are mostly blue states.  So moocher states, if you don't like government programs get rid of them.  But blue, more liberal states, do care about your citizens and thus we don't complain when our money goes your way.(Last I checked, RI was $1 for $1)
Do you think there is any relationship in the opposition to the ACA from insurance companies and the Chamber of Commerce is the lack of union representation in those areas?

All other wealthy democracies have some form of universal health coverage. And in every instance those systems deliver care at much lower cost than American private insurance--and with better health statistics. Indeed, some American health stats are more Third World than first.

But private insurance generates immense profit and Republican governors who so cruelly deny health care to the working poor, people with an entire $1,000/month to splurge, are not concerned with health and humantiy but with money and inhuman ideology.

Medicaid expansion should be a no-brainer, but the GOP govs have neither brain nor heart. And most of these governors, to use their own terminology, preside over "moocher" states. They are eager for every handout to the rich, but as for a low-income child, well, it's time to decrease the surplus population.

Coldness of heart, narrowness of soul, and smallness of mind have become Republican virtues. The American rich are the wealthiest of any democracy, while the poor are the poorest, the American child poverty rate of 23 per cent far surpassing all but Romania. Do the GOP govs want Transylvanian horror?
Refusal to take cash to treat the poor will live in infamy as a nadir of American humanity.

I'm glad that Americans are becoming better educated and more competitive. That's a silver lining in a lackluster economy. And going back to school is a constructive approach to unemployment or underemployment.

At the same time, what about the well-educated who are unemployed or underemployed? I have a top MBA and another graduate degree, and am earning less at the moment than I did 30 years back.

We urgently need more jobs and economic growth.
